<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 177, 163, 191]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 197, 316, 212]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 177, 865, 192]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 198, 865, 212]]<|/det|>
October/November 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[776, 218, 863, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 237, 560, 280]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 297, 369, 312]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 326, 888, 395]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 409, 850, 440]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 438, 848, 453]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 465, 529, 481]]<|/det|>
## Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 494, 728, 509]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 509, 445, 523]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 523, 343, 537]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 537, 599, 552]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

A student measures the angle of incidence \(i\) and the angle of reflection \(r\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 103, 658, 203]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 216, 724, 235]]<|/det|> The student varies the angle of incidence and then plots a graph of \(r\) against \(i\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 246, 358, 264]]<|/det|> What does the graph look like? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 271, 868, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 435, 101, 454]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 435, 685, 455]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the path of a ray of green light through a glass prism. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 465, 816, 485]]<|/det|> The angle of deviation is the angle between the incident ray and the ray leaving the prism. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 489, 700, 610]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 621, 875, 653]]<|/det|> When a ray of white light is incident on the prism, it separates into the colours of the visible spectrum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 663, 831, 682]]<|/det|> What is the name of this effect and which colour of light has the smallest angle of deviation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 689, 524, 829]]<|/det|>

The starting pistol is 450 metres away from the man. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 429, 591, 448]]<|/det|> What is the speed of sound calculated from this observation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 457, 128, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 457, 165, 475]]<|/det|> 150 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 457, 285, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[293, 457, 373, 475]]<|/det|> 300 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 457, 448, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 457, 532, 475]]<|/det|> 330 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[584, 457, 604, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[608, 457, 692, 475]]<|/det|> 625 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 500, 99, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 500, 677, 518]]<|/det|> A bar magnet is slowly moved towards an unmagnetised metal object X. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 526, 690, 586]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 597, 747, 615]]<|/det|> When it is a few centimetres away, the object begins to slide towards the magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 626, 298, 644]]<|/det|> Why does this happen? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 653, 128, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 653, 618, 670]]<|/det|> X is a non-magnetic material and magnetism is induced in it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 678, 128, 695]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 678, 648, 695]]<|/det|> X is a non-magnetic material and magnetism is not induced in it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 703, 128, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 703, 584, 720]]<|/det|> X is a magnetic material and magnetism is induced in it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 728, 128, 745]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 728, 611, 745]]<|/det|> X is a magnetic material and magnetism is not induced in it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 549, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 490, 703, 509]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 624, 870, 644]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 653, 238, 670]]<|/det|>
A \(\mathrm{X}\rightarrow \mathrm{Y}\rightarrow \mathrm{Z}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 679, 238, 696]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 705, 238, 722]]<|/det|>
C \(\mathrm{Z}\rightarrow \mathrm{X}\rightarrow \mathrm{Y}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 731, 240, 749]]<|/det|>
D \(\mathrm{Z}\rightarrow \mathrm{Y}\rightarrow \mathrm{X}\)

<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 362, 648, 381]]<|/det|>
Why are some radioactive sources stored in boxes made from lead?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 389, 128, 407]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 389, 569, 407]]<|/det|>
Lead absorbs emissions from the radioactive sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 415, 128, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 415, 546, 433]]<|/det|>
Lead decreases the half-life of radioactive sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 440, 128, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 440, 544, 457]]<|/det|>
Lead increases the half-life of radioactive sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 465, 128, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 465, 554, 483]]<|/det|>
Lead repels emissions from the radioactive sources.
